article.title: Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov., Isolated From the International Space Station
article.abstract: Four strains belonging to the family of Methylobacteriaceae were isolated from different locations on the International Space Station (ISS) across two consecutive flights.

sections.introduction: The genus Methylobacterium contains more species than any other genera within the family Methylobacteriaceae, order Rhizobiales, and class Alphaproteobacteria (Kelly et al., 2014).
sections.methods: Several surface samples (1 m2) were collected from the ISS during Microbial Tracking–1 flight experiments from 2015 to 2016.
sections.results: This study reports the isolation and identification of four strains belonging to the family Methylobacteriaceae, collected from different locations on the ISS.
sections.discussion: The sequence similarity of these three ISS strains with validly described Methylobacterium species was <99.4% for 16S rRNA gene (Supplementary Table 1) and <97.3% for gyrB gene with the closest being M. indicum SE2.11T.

article.insights_summary: This study reports the isolation and identification of four strains belonging to the family Methylobacteriaceae, collected from different locations on the ISS. The sequence similarity of these three ISS strains with validly described Methylobacterium species was <99.4% for 16S rRNA gene and <97.3% for gyrB gene with the closest being M. indicum SE2.11T.
article.acknowledgments: The research described in this manuscript was performed at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology under a contract with NASA and University of Southern California.
